addressleaf.section: To the right honorable my very singular good Lord the L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England

9 Junij
1592.
M
r
Bodeleie to my L./.

page.lettertext:
fol.19r
May it please yo
r
good L. Because I doe
assure my self,
at
e occurrences of the campe
are advertised from those,
at are acto
rs
there in
place, I should but trouble yo
r
L. w
t
speeches
at
goe heere, w
ch
are often times uncertaine. But
yet to signifie in generall, w
at
is written from
thens, The batterie beganne
e 3 of this moneth,
and were bestowed to
e number of 5000 shotte:
but all in a maner cast away: partly by rea-
son of
e hight of
e Conterscarffe, and partly through
e strength of
e rampartes of
e towne, whiche
were both very large, and firmely compact of
tough and solide mater. They failed also in
their sapping, by meanes of stony places,
at stopped
their passage. Howbeit they attempt it againe in
an other quarter and have devised other strata-
gemes: w
ch
will cost many lives, howsoever they
take effect. And if nothing will prevaile to
the winning of
e place, it is commonly supposed,
that we shall then have an end of this sommers
exploites: w
ch
will offer an opportunitie, to have
her
Ma
ties
last demaunde solicited a freshe, if
e present estate of
e
kinge
doe require it. Where-
in yo
r
L. will vouchesafe to certifie her plea-
sure. I neede not signifie unto
yo
w
e grievous complaint of
e marchantes of
Zeland,
upon
e taking of their shippe,
at came
newly out of
Spaine:
wherof
e states of that
Province have written to her Ma
tie
. But yet the
copie of their complaint, because it is indited in
cholericke termes, and w
t
shewe of great dislike of
e courses
at are taken in their causes in
England,
and for
at I stand in some doubt, it is not otherwise
sent yo
r
L. I have inclosed in this letter, together
with a copie of
e mariners depositions. More-
over
e
states of Zeland
have written letters hither
fol.19v
to request
e
General states
, to joine w
t
them in
this suite, for
e intreating of her Hig
nes
to cause a
present restitution of
e goodes of
e foresaid mar-
chants: w
ch
hath bin imparted all unto me, by
certaine deputies of
e states,
at were appointed
this morning, to repaire unto me about it, and
to require my assistance. Who have told me in
w
at
tune,
ei finde
e marchants of these contreis,
and howe greatly it doth behoove, in regard that
they are many, and are
e chiefest contributo
rs
to
e charges of these warres, to prevent in good
time,
at there come no mischief of this mater,
between
e Englishe and Zeland marchantes, or
other daungerous allteration in the affaires of
this state. I omitted no endevo
r
to per-
suade them w
t
good speeches,
at her Ma
tie
would
give order for
e hearing of their cause w
t
equitie
and favo
r
: and I moved them
e while, to seeke
to moderat, as they might,
e passionat procee-
ding of
e marchantes
at complained: w
ch
I
thought very needeful, to advertise w
t
speede,
and so I take my humble leave. At
e Hage.
June 9 1592.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
